text: Folks, what are your best tips for preparing *great* content outlines for your writers?

elements.text: Folks, what are your best tips for preparing
great
content outlines for your writers?

text:
I have a generic guidelines template which every writer adheres to (tone, layout, please use hemingway, no out of date stats etc)

Then I prepare every brief with keywords, search queries to answer, suggested people to interview, sources to reference, internal posts to use.

Most of the time I write the intro or part of a section if it's something I have first hand knowledge of.

text:
Do you have enough time to oversee them and work closely, or you're looking for more automation and autonomy?

Lately, we pivoted to quickly ordering posts, so we're using a content brief tool (UseTopic) to be precise, which takes care of almost everything, plus it suggests us titles, headings, and extracts AI-rewritten text. Content Harmony, MarketMuse, SurferSEO, Frase and many other tools work in the same way (though I can't attest to their qualities).

If you want to build it yourself:

How familiar your writers are with SEO? Your initial briefs would be more thorough especially if they are not very experienced, thus including:

• main and related keywords, concepts and topics.
• search intent ( + who's the audience for the specific content piece, what do they search for, what's our content/product solve for the main CTAs, or paragraphs with product/service-led storytelling)
• URL
• Title
• Heading structure
• Internal links/related posts
• (Optionally) - pointers under each headline with bullets summarizing what the content should be);
More experienced content writers might not need briefs at all, or just content guidelines and/or your best SEO/Content practices. Bare minimum, at least.

Content Harmony, MarketMuse, SurferSEO, Frase and many other tools work in the same way (though I can't attest to their qualities).

If you want to build it yourself:

main and related keywords, concepts and topics.
search intent ( + who's the audience for the specific content piece, what do they search for, what's our content/product solve for the main CTAs, or paragraphs with product/service-led storytelling)
URL

More experienced content writers might not need briefs at all, or just content guidelines and/or your best SEO/Content practices. Bare minimum, at least.

text: <@UUKNSAKUH> what’s your experience of using these tools? Aren’t their outlines just a rehashing of everything that is already ranking anyway?

elements.text: what’s your experience of using these tools? Aren’t their outlines just a rehashing of everything that is already ranking anyway?

text:
Tools just give you an overview of what's already talked about, making sure you're not to miss it. You're responsible for coming up with your own article structure, even with the current state of the tools (haven't worked with MarketMuse enterprise edition yet). That is until there's a tool that generates a completely custom structure based on your audience insights, product solution, etc.

But I usually avoid falling into the google-knows-best fallacy when using an on-page tool, by having a unique point of view from a product perspective within the meat of the content.

If the product has unique features and solutions, and I talk about their approach in solving a particular problem, e.g. in a how-to step by step almost everyone tackled since it's important "to rank", I'm going to include unique steps and view on the matter, no one else has thought about, or has a stance to, as their products do not work/are not built to solve the problem that way. I'm still having the how-to, but the solution is different.

That's where the bullet summarization in the outlines I usually send comes in.

I'm also trying not to stay too long on the content brief stage with the writers I'm working with. They having more freedom is super important in the long-term.

attachments.title: How to Create Better Content Briefs, Faster - Superpath
attachments.text: Content briefs don't automatically make your content better, but they are key part of an efficient and productive workflow. Anyone who's ever been on the giving or receiving end of a content brief knows this—a good content brief keeps projects on track. It's the best way to scope out a writing project and reduce the risk of major revisions late in the process. Kane Jamison [<https://twitter.com/KaneJamison>] knows this problem well. He started a content agency back in 2012 and has refined a smoo
attachments.fallback: Superpath: How to Create Better Content Briefs, Faster - Superpath

text: Hello everyone, I was wondering if someone here has done or been a part of a team that does account-based marketing at scale, I'd like to ask some questions. Thanks!

text: I wanted to do something like this but it was pricey and more complicated than I was able to invest time in exploring. However, it was for an A/B test I was running. Google Ads directing to different landing pages mimicking the home page wound up being the quick fix.
